WERE THEY?
For over a week Hopkins' undergraduates have been selling
spring sport season tickets to alumni and friends of the institution
throughout the city. They have been telling these men that Johns
Hopkins was going to sell $6,000 worth of tickets. Many of the
buyers shook their heads knowingly and said "it couldn't be done."
The Athletic Council, the Varsity Club and undergraduate
leaders have faith in the ability of the student body to raise the
amount required to carry on spring sports. With but two more
days to go the approximate proceeds amount to something over one
thousand dollars.
Some of the teams, however, may be holding back for a whirlwind finish. Many tickets can be sold in two days.
Will they be? Were the skeptics right?

The Johns

Hopkins News-Letter

DANGER!
The Cotillon Board is to be complimented for its endeavors
which have resulted in causing the Saturday afternoon tea-dances to
become established Hopkins institutions. Undergraduates and alumni, in increasing numbers, have found the Civil Engineering Hall a
pleasant rendezvous where a few hours may be spent in a strictly
Hopkins atmosphere with Hopkins spirit abounding.
Coincident with this rise in popularity, however, appears an element—a group of outsiders—which, if it cannot be termed undesirable, is certainly, alien to Hopkins spirit and Hopkins traditions.
These individuals, regular patrons of dov9n-town tea-rooms and
dance floors, have found the nominal fee charged at Homewood attractive and have condescended to place the C. E. Hall on their
weekly calling list. In increasing numbers they are deserting their
former haunts and the C. E. Hall is tending to become a public
rather than a Hopkins dance floor.
If this tendency grows Hopkins men will soon find other places
take
their girls on Saturday afternoon. It does not seem necesto
sary to entirely exclude outsiders. The affairs should be limited,
however, to Hopkins undergraduates, alumni and their friends by
placing a restrictive admission charge on all others.
TALK HOPKINS
"Johns Hopkins? Why, I thought that was a hospital?"
Undergraduates of half a decade ago frequently heard this and
similar remarks. Hopkins was known for its excellent graduate
schools, but the nation was not aware of the fact that undergraduate activities existed.
In recent years, however, there has been a marked change. No
more is Johns Hopkins known only as a hospital. Its athletic teams
have brought undergraduate activities before the nation's eyes, its
Glee Club, its publications and other student activities have helped
to advertise the University. The same high standards of scholarship have been maintained; activities have made rapid strides in
the right direction.
There is still, however, plenty of room for advertisement. The
spring holidays begin this week and a large proportion of the undergraduate body will leave Baltimore for other places, places where
•Hopkins is not so well known.
Forget your, studies, if you wish, during the holidays. But
don't forget Hopkins. Advertise it whenever and wherever you
obtain opportunity. Tell preparatory schckl boys and their fond
parents what a good old place it is.
Talk liopkins!

IN fiction and the movies all college men naturally fall into two groups. Those who pass
their days and nights "Rah! Rah!"-ing and
snake-dancing; and those who never appear
except with evening clothes—and cane.
The man who works his way through college
simply doesn't figure.
Taking care of a furnace, running a laundry,
waiting on table, tutoring, covering for .a city
paper, working in shop or office in vacation—
all this may be lacking in romantic appeal, but
it is an essential part of the college picture.
And a valuable part. The whole college is
the gainer for the earnestness of men who want
their education that hard.
Valuable to the college, but even more to the
men who travel this rough going. They learn
an important lesson in Applied Economics—
the amount of sweat a ten dollar bill represents.
If you are one of them you may sometimes
feel that you are missing a good deal of worthwhile college life. If you are not, you may be
missing a good deal, too.

WERE THEY?
For over a week Hopkins' undergraduates have been selling
spring sport season tickets to alumni and friends of the institution
throughout the city. They have been telling these men that Johns
Hopkins was going to sell $6,000 worth of tickets. Many of the
buyers shook their heads knowingly and said "it couldn't be done."
The Athletic Council, the Varsity Club and undergraduate
leaders have faith in the ability of the student body to raise the
amount required to carry on spring sports. With but two more
days to go the approximate proceeds amount to something over one
thousand dollars.
Some of the teams, however, may be holding back for a whirlwind finish. Many tickets can be sold in two days.
Will they be? Were the skeptics right?

The Johns

Hopkins News-Letter

DANGER!
The Cotillon Board is to be complimented for its endeavors
which have resulted in causing the Saturday afternoon tea-dances to
become established Hopkins institutions. Undergraduates and alumni, in increasing numbers, have found the Civil Engineering Hall a
pleasant rendezvous where a few hours may be spent in a strictly
Hopkins atmosphere with Hopkins spirit abounding.
Coincident with this rise in popularity, however, appears an element—a group of outsiders—which, if it cannot be termed undesirable, is certainly, alien to Hopkins spirit and Hopkins traditions.
These individuals, regular patrons of dov9n-town tea-rooms and
dance floors, have found the nominal fee charged at Homewood attractive and have condescended to place the C. E. Hall on their
weekly calling list. In increasing numbers they are deserting their
former haunts and the C. E. Hall is tending to become a public
rather than a Hopkins dance floor.
If this tendency grows Hopkins men will soon find other places
take
their girls on Saturday afternoon. It does not seem necesto
sary to entirely exclude outsiders. The affairs should be limited,
however, to Hopkins undergraduates, alumni and their friends by
placing a restrictive admission charge on all others.
TALK HOPKINS
"Johns Hopkins? Why, I thought that was a hospital?"
Undergraduates of half a decade ago frequently heard this and
similar remarks. Hopkins was known for its excellent graduate
schools, but the nation was not aware of the fact that undergraduate activities existed.
In recent years, however, there has been a marked change. No
more is Johns Hopkins known only as a hospital. Its athletic teams
have brought undergraduate activities before the nation's eyes, its
Glee Club, its publications and other student activities have helped
to advertise the University. The same high standards of scholarship have been maintained; activities have made rapid strides in
the right direction.
There is still, however, plenty of room for advertisement. The
spring holidays begin this week and a large proportion of the undergraduate body will leave Baltimore for other places, places where
•Hopkins is not so well known.
Forget your, studies, if you wish, during the holidays. But
don't forget Hopkins. Advertise it whenever and wherever you
obtain opportunity. Tell preparatory schckl boys and their fond
parents what a good old place it is.
Talk liopkins!

IN fiction and the movies all college men naturally fall into two groups. Those who pass
their days and nights "Rah! Rah!"-ing and
snake-dancing; and those who never appear
except with evening clothes—and cane.
The man who works his way through college
simply doesn't figure.
Taking care of a furnace, running a laundry,
waiting on table, tutoring, covering for .a city
paper, working in shop or office in vacation—
all this may be lacking in romantic appeal, but
it is an essential part of the college picture.
And a valuable part. The whole college is
the gainer for the earnestness of men who want
their education that hard.
Valuable to the college, but even more to the
men who travel this rough going. They learn
an important lesson in Applied Economics—
the amount of sweat a ten dollar bill represents.
If you are one of them you may sometimes
feel that you are missing a good deal of worthwhile college life. If you are not, you may be
missing a good deal, too.
